case_vignette: A 7-year-old boy presents to an urgent care center for a rash that began approximately 2 days ago. According to his mother, it began as a pink rash on his face and has subsequently spread to his trunk. The child was adopted and has not yet begun care with his pediatrician. His temperature is 100.2°F (37.9°C), blood pressure is 104/74 mmHg, pulse is 99/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the rash in Figure A and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The child is otherwise interactive and is quietly playing with toys.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

Have you had any recent changes in your appetite or weight?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in my appetite or weight.
Have you had any recent exposure to any new animals or insects?
I don't know about any recent exposure to new animals or insects.
Have you had any recent travel or changes in your environment?
I haven't had any recent travel or changes in my environment.

No, there haven't been any changes in my diet or lifestyle recently.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or supplements?
I haven't started any new medications or supplements.
Have you had any recent changes in your family history or medical history?
I was adopted, so I don't have full details about my family or medical history.
Final Diagnosis: Roseola.
